comments.commentBody: So $280,000,000 multiplied by 58 days, (with the meter running)is $16,240,000,000 (sixteen billion dollars and change).

Put them out of business......it's time for accountability to return to our culture!
In retrospect it's clear to see that we should have never bailed out financial institutions in 2008.......
BP doesn't deserve to be in business here.......and should never be allowed to pump one drop of oil from underneath our lands.....

President Obama said that it is important that BP remain viable so that they can bear the costs of the cleanup and restitution to the Gulf businesspeople. However, I would like to know why BP cannot be liquidated now with all proceeds going to the Gulf recovery fund.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
This is exactly what is wrong with thinking in America today. Define "now." Maybe put BP up on EBay? How about an ad on CraigsList?

Do you have any idea how much time it takes to liquidate even a small business, much less one of the world's largest corporations? It could take years, if it could even be done. Please people, think!

There's a story in the NY Times today about the ongoing oil catastrophe {Shell and Exxon) in Nigeria. There is Crude:the movie about the ongoing oil catastrophe {Chevron/Texaco)in Ecuador. We only seem to care when the oil is literally lapping our own shores. Of course mainstream media doesn't report these stories.
The oil companies and their massive lobbying and marketing force will be fighting regulations and lawsuits, and any changes in our energy policy, with everything they have.

Chevron sponsors The NewsHour on PBS, along with Monsanto(out to control the world through genetic modifications and patents).What kind of coverage can we expect from even public television when these less than benign corporations sponsor the news??? Exxon sponsors Gwen Ifell's Washington Week. Do you think these corporations are sponsoring news and talk shows for the public good??? We need an outcry from the public to get rid of corporate sponsorship of the news on PBS!

#6: "All this blather is steadily ensuring that the US becomes irrelevant. That's how empires die and Obama, like his war criminal predecessor, is doing everything he can do [to] make sure that happens."

------------------------

Oh, please.

This whole Obama-in-a-dark-castle-on-a-jagged-cliff-in-a-raging-thunderstorm-holding-up-a-bony-index-finger-and-declaring-"The-world- shall-be-mine!" schtick is just too much!

I guess "unfounded paranoia" can be added to the already very long list of the effects of conservative governance.

I've said for years that in corporate cases, after compensation for victims has been settled, criminal and civil charges should hold INDIVIDUALS accountable in terms of a combination of jail time and monetary impoverishment. If those who make the decisions know they can't just skip out on the company once things go bad or stay and still get their pay and bonuses, that they will go to jail and have to pay heavy fines, they will be more careful, whether it is oil, finance, auto or any other industry.

The criminal probe should include the employees of the Federal Government who approved the well and signed the permits. They are even more guilty of negligence. It was their job to PREVENT disasater and they completely failed at their job.  The job of BP is to drill, subject to existing regulatory constraints. The job of the Feds is to SUPERVISE and to PREVENT. Our President should target 70% of his verbal attacks at his own employees.

Perhaps some women would like this, at least if it turns out more effective than it sounds. But, should it become available, I imagine a considerable fraction of the women taking it will be doing so solely at the request of their (male) partners. The best I can say about that is that it's better than whatever they were doing at Stepford.

I blame the drafters of the current DSM, for creating the spurious, unscientific and essentially *political* "disease" diagnosis of "hypoactive sexual desire disorder."

These people are supposed to be experts with years of experience treating psychological problems, and yet it only takes a second or two of reflection to realize that any problem involving either "too much" or "too little" sexual desire resides with a COUPLE, not in an individual. The problem is *mismatched* sexual desire, and it's a *social* problem, not a psychological problem.

Since it's far more often the women in heterosexual relationships who have less interest in sex, the DSM is basically "siding with the men." And now Boehringer is about to train both barrels of its market power at the women. This will only lead to that much more pressure on women, particularly straight women, to have sex and be sexy all the time.

It's nice to know that a male doctor has decided that yet another female pathological condition exists. Let me get this straight - this drug does nothing to lift the depression it was designed to cure, but increases libido. You can be sad and sexy at the same time - who knew? You might get nauseous and dizzy too. But if it makes you more of a woman, so what?

I can see the warning label now: "Before engaging in sexual activity, bring a barf bowl to bed with you. Dizziness may occur, but your partner will think you're just fainting from excitement."

If the FDA has any sense, and is not completely corrupted by drug company insiders, this medication will not be approved. Let the doctor who thinks it's such a godsend take a dose himself and see how it works out for him.

<< Lisa Rinna, a soap opera star and former Playboy model... describes herself as someone who has suffered from a disorder that Boehringer refers to as a form of “female sexual dysfunction.”

I am wondering if the good Dr. Peter has considered the numerous cosmetic surgeries Ms. Rinna has undergone. Could she be suffering from something other than "a form of female sexual dysfunction”? As for the same diagnosis of a 40-something care giver of both children and ailing mother, I can only roll my eyes.

I guess someone forgot to tell my workacholic-post-menopause spouse that she is suppose to be tired. After 19years, we still find time to go out on dates & in private she has more desire now than before. OH! yes I cook, clean and wash our laundry. ...but it does help that Iam 13years younger. Trust me ...she has a lot of energy for another 19years.

If someone has a problem, the first step is to figure out what's causing the problem--not to just give it a label and prescribe a pill.

My guess is that many women with "hypoactive sexual desire" would be cured if they found a reasonably attractive man who gave them respect, attention and love and was a skilled and passionate lover. If that doesn't do it, they are probably clinically depressed, overstressed and/or overworked. I don't see how any of that is going to be cured with this pill.

I agree with Writer No. 17.  My wife is postmenopausal.  Prior to menopause, we had an extraordinarily active and wonderful sex life.  I am a compassionate and loving male, and she is a compassionate and loving woman, but since menopause, her libido has been zero.  So it's psychological, huh?  Well, she couldn't wait for menopause.  Now it's been one of her worse curses.  I have been very concerned about her and very supportive, so don't lay that on me, No. 7!  You who turn up your noses at the idea of a physical problem here are likely either totally disinterested in sex and thrilled that you no longer have any sexual desire, or those who'd like to blame everything on psychological problems.  Well, Ladies Who Are Happy To Be Postmenopausal, good for you.  I'm glad you're happy that you don't have any interest in one of God's greatest gifts.  Enjoy your "freedom."  Sorry you don't "Get It."  Sexual dysfunction of females is complicated and many-faceted.  But if a pill with relatively minor side effects helps some women, I'm all for it.  Bet if Viagra only helped a few, all of you men would be all for it!

So typical of our pharmaceutical industry - to create a syndrome that many can feel they have, sponsor some studies, hire some academic physicians to claim their medicine can ail what may be a normal variant, and develop a medicine with very marginal effectiveness - all to rake in the profit.

@ no. 17 "Postmenopausal women may need help, as well, because their husbands, who are probably just as old but have access to Viagra or other enhancing drugs in the event of difficulties, would presumably still like to have sex."

Why should the mere fact that a woman's husband wants to have sex when she doesn't mean that *she* has to take a pill?
The sale of the men’s drugs Viagra will multiply in competition.
A women's sexual desire and appetite is only limited by her partners inhibitions..and imagination..!

Wow, there are some great comments on this - yes, it sounds like just one more way to manipulate women and men's expectations of them. I'm surprised that noone (particularly in the article!) seems to be talking about the fact that women's lack of desire for sex is sometimes linked to a history of, oh, say, sexual abuse? And the expectation of a particular kind of libido, for men or women can easily be linked to, oh, say, compulsive behavior? Enough with expectations and controlling of women's bodies!

Thanks to all the post-menopausal women who chimed in - what a perspective!

Any  time an army is turned loose to deal with internal issues is troubling. Repression by dictators and tyrants is so often covered by "maintaing civil order", or worse fending off a populist uprising. The Stans of eastern and central asia, often sit on strategic crossroads, or, seem to have exploitable raw resources, read Afghanistan of late. The United States continues in the vein of supporting brutal governments because it is often American, American related interests that have the relationship established with that repressive government. Until we can break this cycle of  support for corrupt and murderous pols, we will be doomed to relive the last 100 years all over again.

"Hidden hands" and cabals are speculated in this article and elsewhere. "Politics."  100k (~1.8153%) of the population of a country fled to the country next door. Spontaneously, in a matter of days. No military buildup or PR campaign, no tanks and bullhorns in the streets. All refugees members of an ethnic minority. Politics may be the match, but with numbers like that, could it really be the fuel? Smacks of ethnic violence in the Caucasus. But what if it's really centralized control, cabals and hidden hands? A couple of guys fighting for the crown. I'm not saying yes or no. But if yes, god do we live in a brave new world.

It is very unfortunate that the most people in the world are so distracted with either the sanction in Iran or FIFA World Cup while these people are being killed.. Can we as humans EVER learn to NOT repeat the horrors of Holocaust, Kosovo or Darfur? My prayer and thoughts are with the separated Uzbek families who are constantly fearing for their lives...

So, which people are more important to Congress, hedge fund manages or the unemployed? The above says it all. The unemployed lose COBRA subsidies, the $25 extra a week (which was a life line), no extension in benefits (no new tier) and more days go by when the benefits expired over two weeks ago. But, the winners here, hedge fund managers who can fund campaigns fro Congress. Another glaring example that Congress represents those who have the most wealth, and their actions on legislation since January, 2009, were spending bills and new laws that help the special interests, well connected, but not the people.

By the way, what this article does not mention is that Congress approved extending the home buyer's credit today. More money for people who don't need it and less money for people who do. What a travesty.

Finally, I'm glad that I finally got a job and I hope I never have to see unemployment benefits ever again. Funny, Congress created the climate for unemployment and they are punishing the unemployed because of their own self serving actions by providing benefits to their benefactors. As each day goes by, this country is sinking into a cesspool.
It seems that BP has handled yet another PR moment by senior management as clumsily and ineffectively as they've handled operations and safety at the Deep Horizon Rig

Augustine 25, clicking on your name reveals that you are a professor.  As a college freshman, I knew what political axes my college professors were grinding: You are grinding hatred for Obama.  So, you will forgive me if doubt your word.  BP caused this oil spill and environmental disaster, not the government.  Since you oppose government intervention, I assume that you oppose the $20 billion plus escrow account that Obama forced BP to establish.  If BP refuses to honor its commitment to pay all of the expenses, then you know who will be stuck with the bill: The Little People as BP’s chairman so eloquently stated it this afternoon, and the little people are the US taxpayers.
